item.title: Research: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
item.description:
Abstract

Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) allows an attacker to induce the server-side application to make HTTP requests to an arbitrary domain of the attacker’s choosing. This is particularly dangerous in cloud environments where servers often have access to metadata services or internal admin panels.

1. Localhost Bypass

Many applications trust requests coming from localhost (127.0.0.1).

Scenario: A stock check API takes a URL parameter: stockApi=http://stock.weliketoshop.net:8080/product/stock

The Attack: By changing the URL to the loopback address, we can access services listening on the local server that are blocked from the outside world (like an Admin Interface).
item.content:
Abstract

Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) allows an attacker to induce the server-side application to make HTTP requests to an arbitrary domain of the attacker’s choosing. This is particularly dangerous in cloud environments where servers often have access to metadata services or internal admin panels.

1. Localhost Bypass

Many applications trust requests coming from localhost (127.0.0.1).

Scenario: A stock check API takes a URL parameter: stockApi=http://stock.weliketoshop.net:8080/product/stock

The Attack: By changing the URL to the loopback address, we can access services listening on the local server that are blocked from the outside world (like an Admin Interface).

Payload: stockApi=http://localhost/admin

Once access is confirmed, we can execute administrative actions (e.g., deleting users) by crafting the full path: http://localhost/admin/delete?username=carlos

2. Scanning Internal Networks

If the server can connect to other machines in the internal network, SSRF can be used as a port scanner.

Technique: We can fuzz the last octet of the IP address to discover other active hosts on the subnet.

  • Target: 192.168.0.X:8080/admin
  • Automation: Using Burp Intruder to iterate X from 1 to 255.

Findings: In this assessment, the internal admin panel was discovered at 192.168.0.30. This confirms the vulnerability allows for lateral movement discovery within the DMZ.

Impact

  • Cloud Metadata Access: (AWS: http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/)
  • Internal Port Scanning: Mapping the internal network topology.
  • Access to Internal APIs: Interacting with microservices that lack authentication.
